# Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## What is an Externality?
:::{.nonincremental}
- An **externality** is a side effect of a market transaction—positive or negative—that affects the **well-being of people who are not directly involved** as buyers or sellers.
  - **Negative externality**: imposes costs on others (e.g., air pollution from autos).
  - **Positive externality**: confers benefits on others (e.g., tree planting—amenity value, carbon uptake, habitat).
- Comprehensive analysis must account for **all members of society** (and possibly ecosystems), not only buyers and sellers.

:::

::: callout-tip
**Key idea:** Markets maximize total surplus **only** when *all* marginal costs and benefits are internal to decision‑makers.
:::

## The Market for Automobiles
::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-1.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}

- **Supply curve** ≈ **PMC**: private marginal cost of producing one more unit (labor, materials, energy, etc.).
- **Demand curve** ≈ **PMB**: private marginal benefit (consumers’ willingness‑to‑pay for one more unit).

:::
::::

- **Market equilibrium $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$** is efficient **only if** PMC = SMC and PMB = SMB (i.e., no externalities).


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.1 (explained)**: For automobiles, demand intersects supply at $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$. With no externalities, this point maximizes total private surplus. -->
<!-- ::: -->


## Accounting for Environmental Costs

- Auto production & use create multiple **negative externalities**: local/regional air pollution, CO₂, water contamination, toxic wastes, habitat loss, road salt runoff, congestion.
- These costs **do not appear** in the private supply curve; hence **market overstates net social benefits** at $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$.
- We must **internalize** external costs to evaluate the market’s true impact.


## EPA Endangerment Finding on GHG Emissions

- **Proposal Date**: July 29, 2025 — EPA formally proposed rescinding the 2009 Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Endangerment Finding ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)).
- **Statutory Impact**: Without the Endangerment Finding, EPA would **lose authority under CAA §202(a)** to regulate GHG emissions from motor vehicles ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding); [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_greenhouse_gases_under_the_Clean_Air_Act)).
  - CAA §202(a) is the EPA’s authority to regulate tailpipe pollution from new vehicles when it threatens public health or welfare.
- **Regulatory Effect**: Proposal includes **removal of GHG standards** for light-, medium-, and heavy-duty vehicles and engines ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)). 
- **What Remains**: Standards for **criteria pollutants, toxic emissions, corporate average fuel economy (CAFE), and labeling** will **not be changed**([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/regulations-emissions-vehicles-and-engines/proposed-rule-reconsideration-2009-endangerment-finding)). 


## EPA Endangerment Finding: Process & Reactions

<div style="display:block; margin:-10px;"></div>

- **Public Hearing & Comment Period**:
  - Public hearings held August 19–21 (and possibly August 22), 2025.  
  - Comment deadline extended from September 15 to **September 22, 2025** ([Federal Register](https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/08/15/2025-15512/reconsideration-of-2009-endangerment-finding-and-greenhouse-gas-vehicle-standards-extension-of); [Office of Advocacy](https://advocacy.sba.gov/2025/08/15/epa-extends-comment-period-for-proposed-repeal-of-greenhouse-gas-endangerment-finding-and-vehicle-emissions-rules/); [Holland & Knight](https://www.hklaw.com/en/insights/publications/2025/08/up-in-the-air-epa-opens-comment-on-repealing-endangerment-finding)).

- **Deregulatory Framing**:
  - The proposal is presented as part of a broader **deregulatory agenda**, hailed as one of the **largest in U.S. history** ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/what-they-are-saying-leaders-praise-epa-launching-largest-deregulatory-action-us)).
  - EPA claims the repeal could save Americans **$54 billion annually** and **$170 billion for small businesses** ([US EPA](https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-releases-proposal-rescind-obama-era-endangerment-finding-regulations-paved-way)).

- **Criticisms**:
  - Critics argue the rule **ignores scientific consensus** and is legally weak, potentially dismantling key rules and safeguards designed to protect against climate change ([The Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2025/07/22/endangerment-finding-epa-climate)).

## Valuing Damages
:::{.nonincremental}
- Assign **monetary values** to external harms to build **SMC**:
  - Direct costs (e.g., **water treatment** for contaminated sources).
  - **Health damages** (medical expenses, morbidity, mortality risk).
  - **Aesthetic/amenity** losses (visibility, recreation quality).
  - **Ecosystem** impacts (biodiversity, habitat quality).
- If we assign no value, the market implicitly assigns **zero**—biasing decisions.

:::

::: callout-warning
Valuation aggregates **tangible** and **intangible** impacts; precision is hard, but **order‑of‑magnitude** estimates guide better policy than zeros.
:::


## The Market for Automobiles with Negative Externalities

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-2.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **SMC = PMC + EMC**, where **EMC** is the *external marginal cost*.
- Typically, **EMC rises** with output when pollution/congestion intensify.

:::
::::

- **SMC** lies **above** **PMC** by the vertical distance equal to EMC.


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.2 (explained):** SMC above supply (PMC). Efficient quantity **$Q^{*}$** occurs where **SMC** intersects demand (PMB). For any $Q>$Q^{*}$$, SMC > MB ⇒ society worse off at the margin. -->
<!-- ::: -->

# Internalizing Environmental Costs {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Automobile Market with Pigovian Tax

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-3.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- Impose a **per‑unit tax** $t$ equal to **EMC at $Q^{*}$**.
- Effect: raises firms’ **marginal private cost** so the *effective* supply coincides with **SMC**.

:::
::::

- New equilibrium: **$(P^{*}, Q^{*})$**—the **socially efficient** outcome.


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.3 (explained):** Supply with tax overlaps SMC; price rises to **P^{*}**, quantity falls to **$Q^{*}$**. Burden shared by consumers (higher price) and producers (lower net‑of‑tax receipts), depending on elasticities. -->
<!-- ::: -->

## Practical Design Choices

- **Set the right tax**: Requires damage estimation (economics + science).
- **Administrative cost** vs **benefit**: Not every small externality warrants a bespoke tax.
- **Upstream taxes**: Levy at **raw inputs** (fossil fuels, toxic chemicals, ores) to simplify coverage; costs ripple downstream to products according to input intensity.
- **Revenue recycling**: Use proceeds for **rebates**, **tax credits**, **rate relief**, or **public goods** to address equity/political feasibility.


## Incidence & Elasticities

- Tax burden split depends on **price elasticities** of supply and demand.
- Steeper (less elastic) side bears **more** burden.
- Common claim “firms pass it all on” is generally **false**; division is empirical.


## Distributional Concerns
:::{.nonincremental}
- Many environmental taxes (e.g., on fuels) can be **regressive**.
- Policy package can include **lump‑sum rebates**, **earned income credits**, or **targeted transfers** to protect **low‑income** households.
:::

::: callout-tip
A 2013 estimate put global primary‑industry externalities near **$7.3T (~13% of world output)**; in magnitude, **comprehensive Pigovian systems** could rival global tax revenues—raising ideas of **tax swaps**. (Use with caution; orders of magnitude, not precise policy blueprints.)
:::


# Positive Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## The Market for Solar Energy with Positive Externalities


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-4.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **SMB = PMB + EMB**, where **EMB** is *external marginal benefit*.

:::
::::

- Examples: **solar panels** (emissions reductions), **vaccinations**, **R&D spillovers**, **urban trees**.



<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.4 (explained):** SMB lies **above** demand by the vertical EMB. Market stops at **QM**, but **$Q^{*}$** is larger because **SMB > SMC** for units between QM and $Q^{*}$. -->
<!-- ::: -->

## The Market for Solar Energy with a Subsidy


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-5.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- A **producer subsidy** of $s$ per unit **lowers** effective marginal cost (downward supply shift).
- A **consumer subsidy / tax credit** **raises** effective willingness‑to‑pay (upward demand shift).

:::
::::

- **Correct subsidy** aligns the market with **$Q^{*}$** where **SMC = SMB**.



<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.5 (explained):** With the subsidy, equilibrium quantity expands to **$Q^{*}$**; price effects differ for producers vs consumers, but the quantity target is the same. -->
<!-- ::: -->

# Welfare Analysis of Externalities {background-color="#1c4982"}

## Welfare Analysis of the Automobile Market


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-6.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}


- **Consumer Surplus (CS):** Area **under demand** and **above price**.
- **Producer Surplus (PS):** Area **above supply (PMC)** and **below price**.

:::
::::

- Without externalities, equilibrium maximizes **CS + PS**.



<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.6 (explained):** At $(P_{M}, Q_{M})$, CS = area **A**; PS = area **B**. -->
<!-- ::: -->

## Welfare Analysis of the Automobile Market with Externalities

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-7.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}

- With a negative externality, true **net social welfare** is:
  $$
  \begin{align}
  &\quad\;\; \text{NSW}\\ 
  \,&=\, (\text{CS} + \text{PS}) \\
  &\;\,- \text{External Damages}.
  \end{align}
  $$

:::
::::


- External damages are the area **between PMC and SMC** up to the chosen quantity.


<!-- ::: callout-note -->
<!-- **Figure 3.7 (explained):** At **QM**, net welfare = **A' + B' − C**. Triangle **C** is the **deadweight loss** from overproduction where **SMC > MB**. -->
<!-- ::: -->

## Pigovian Tax Improves Welfare

::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="67.5%"}

<div style="text-align: center; width: 75%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/hr-fig3-8.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

:::

::: {.column width="32.5%"}

- Set tax so that the equilibrium moves to **$Q^{*}$**.
- **Tax revenue** equals the **external damages at $Q^{*}$** (rectangle **D**): revenue can **compensate** for damages.

:::
::::

- Net social welfare becomes **A'' + B''**, which equals **A' + B'**; hence welfare **rises by C** relative to the unregulated outcome.


<!-- ::: callout-tip -->
<!-- **Takeaway:** Properly set **taxes/subsidies eliminate the deadweight loss** created by externalities and **increase net social welfare**. -->
<!-- ::: -->

<!-- ## Deadweight Loss (DWL) — Definition -->

<!-- - **DWL** is the loss in total surplus relative to the efficient outcome. -->
<!-- - With negative externalities and no policy: DWL is the triangle **between $Q^{*}$** and **QM** where **SMC > MB**. -->


## Optimal Pollution
:::{.nonincremental}
- **Zero pollution** generally implies **zero production**; instead, economists seek the **efficient** (not necessarily zero) level of pollution given current technology and preferences.
- The **Pigovian tax** yields **optimal (residual) pollution**—the remaining damages at **$Q^{*}$**.
- Caveat: If demand shifts right (e.g., autos more valued), the **efficient** pollution level can rise—raising questions about **science‑based caps** vs **pure efficiency**.
:::

::: callout-warning
Policy practice often sets **health‑based standards** (e.g., the Clean Air Act) and then uses market instruments to **achieve** those standards cost‑effectively.
:::
